pros: I have been working at St. Ann's for almost five years. It is large enough that we can enjoy great benefits, but small enough that the work environment is close and family-like. There are many opportunities for growth within. There is an excellent tuition reimbursement program and an employee scholarship program to assist with on-going education. I feel that my opinion carries weight and is valued by leadership. There are many fun events for staff - holiday parties, employee picnics, employee and family carnival, and more, as well as a great recognition program. There are many opportunities for non-caregivers to engage with residents.
cons: Each opportunity is what you make of it. Sure, there will always be challenges in every workplace, but the appreciation and kindness I have experienced here from residents, family members, peers, and leaders have far outweighed any challenges that have come my way.

pros: Great residents and staff in many departments with exception to the Marketing Department.  The best part of the position is working with families and helping seniors.
cons: The Marketing Department has upper management  that is out of touch with the basics of leadership and management.  They have created a revolving door of talented people leaving the company.   The company seems to be focused on leadership and retention but yet this continues to escalate.

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Rochester, NY
pros: Great place for new nurses to learn. They are very patience. We are experiencing a lot more acute issues so more nursing skills are being used.
cons: Understaffed has been a real problem recently. It has gotten pretty bad making it impossible to preform job properly. For the amount of work that is expected nurses are very underpaid.

pros: OK benefits if you let them work for you.  Middle-management is fair.  Awesome cafeteria.  Great community involvement.  Decent colleauges.
cons: My particular position was completely different from those in my category.  Responsibilities were not clear.  Upper management is very unprofessional.  Termination policy is unfair.

pros: St. Ann’s Community is a great place to work if you want to make a meaningful contribution, connect with others, and be recognized.
cons: Can be a high emotional investment. Best environment for people willing to give it 100% each day, with a positive attitude, and keen ability to find the best in others.

pros:
Great staff
Caring organization
More like a family than a company
Focus on education and promoting current employees - upward mobility is very possible here.
cons: Residents and patients are great - medically complex - nurses must have a good skill set!

pros: building relationships with residents and families
cons:
The management and higher up employees seem to not care about the residents
At St. Ann's, as an employee, you're just a number.
They allow resident abuse and neglect.
Horrible pay
 Seem to only care about private paying residents,
 I thought I was anonymously reporting abuse and my name given away.  
Hold education courses but only higher up workers can go, so the aides and nurses never get to attend the education courses.
CEO only came on the units twice during my time there.

pros: Excellent team, positive environment, fantastic boss, excellent supporting staff, and amazing residents.
cons: MDS based duties, frequent requests or duties that take away from nutrition assessment duties, weekend leadership rounding (without the paycheck to reflect leadership), slow paced w/ limited need for clinical judgment.

pros: Great pay, benefits and wonderful staff make St. Ann's an excellent place to work!  They offer scholarships, leadership courses and promote employee recognition.
cons: Whenever I had a problem, it was resolved.

pros: Great progressive organization. New CEO trying to do right by residents and employees. His new strategic plan centers everything around the employee
cons: High employee turn-over, mostly during the first year.

review_title: I really enjoy my job and look forward to going to work everyday.
pros: great atmosphere, great team of people,
cons: short staffed workins overtime frequently

pros: This has by far been hands down the best atmosphere and insurance I've ever had I enjoy all my co-workers. I'm continuously greatful. A very adapting enviroment to peoples needs and looking always for ways to improve it further.
cons: I wish there was more positions that was possible to slide into or advance too. Most things require more education. This is not a negative reflection on them, but probably the nature of the enviroment. But they do plan to expand soon.

review_title: If you want to work for a CMS 1 quality star hospital, this is your place
pros: Fairly competitive wages, yet they are still short staffed in all departments.
cons:
Has significantly gone downhill in recent years. 

CMS Quality Star rating decreased to 1 star in 2021. Glassdoor will not let me post a link, google “Beckers Hospital Review 2021 CMS 1 star hospitals” and you will find the article detailing all 1 quality star rated hospitals in the US.  Columbia Memorial is the only 1 star hospital in the state of Oregon. 

Micromanagement by administration has a chokehold on department managers that is beyond stifling. Do not seem to accept/seek/consider input from managers, instead issue directives re managing of departments, which are often harmful to department due to administrations lack of knowledge and unwillingness to ask for or listen to input from those most familiar with department functions. Happens across the board in most departments. 

Administration bullies managers/staff and providers. 

There is a severe lack of respect for doctors in this organization that starts from the very top of administration, including the COOs refusal to address physicians by their professional titles, a conscious attempt to undermine their leadership role in healthcare and demote them in perception. 

This organizations primary focus is profits. They claim to be saving to build a new hospital, but executives are paid extremely well for a rural critical access hospital.

They perpetually fail to maintain adequate staffing levels. This was true before COVID and has only gotten worse.

review_title: It's pretty good for small town employment especially
pros: The benefits are good.  The job itself is never boring.  There is some room for growth,  if you meet productivity and quality standards.
cons: The quality and productivity standards are very strict.  Negative feedback outweighs the positive feedback times a thousand.

pros: Good benefits and earned leave/sick days.
cons: Nepotism, favoritism, pits employees against each other.

review_title: Not a great place to work
job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Astoria, OR
pros: They make an effort to put art in the rooms and make the hospital look nice. They are part of several big initiatives and are growing and changing at a rapid pace.
cons: Pay is below the market average. For example Providence pays their entry level certified medical assistants more. Their health insurance was also horrible and came with a laundry list of over 30+ things that they would not provide you coverage for. They don't provide training and you really aren't supported in your role.

review_title: Horrible Environment.  Unacceptable, bullyish behavior by supervisors.
pros: Working with the members of the community.  Many of the co-workers are amazing.  The pay (not the benefits) is pretty good.
cons: Constant favoritism.  If you are a favorite, then your job is secure.  If you aren't, you will be micromanaged to the point of a breakdown or just walking out the door.  Three people have already done that in the last month in my department.   They sell the whole Planetree / Just Culture crap at orientation, but they do not live up to it.  There is nothing 'just' about the way the staff is treated.  There is motivation by humiliation and intimidation and the constant threat of losing your job.  If you are a good suck up, you can get away with anything.  The union stewards who are supposed to be there to support the staff aren't trust worthy either .  It is just horrible.  The patient access supervisor is a nightmare to work under.  If she likes you, you are golden.  If she doesn't, there will be nothing that you can do right. No matter how hard you try, she will find something to complain about and always makes sure that it is in an email so that it can be taken to HR when she wants to get rid of you.  Standing up for yourself is not tolerated by her.    I don't think that this behavior is part of her job, it just appears that she is a controlling, bullyish person.   She uses intimidation and nastiness to get a compliant staff.  Actually, happy people who feel appreciated make better employees.  They also make less frequent mistakes. People who aren't constantly worrying about being fired for something that the supervisor assumes they did or what someone else says they did, will stay longer.  CEO seems to be oblivious to what goes on.  Or maybe he just doesn't care.  The job itself is wonderful and the patients are great to work with, even when they are grumpy.  The hospital and town are so beautiful and this could be such a great place to work if the CEO would take some input from those of us at the bottom of the totem pole.  AND THEN MAKE CHANGES.

pros: Very nice facility, clean and non cluttered.
cons: Many of the management team are the very definition of workplace bullies.  Lying is a common theme, non violent bullying & use of various scare techniques. Cliques are the true leaders, as the CEO and Assistant Vice Presidents stay hidden and promote inner turmoil and conflict.

pros: Clean hospital and clinic & great cafeteria. Honestly, my outlook on CMH is so negative because of all the cons and the experience I had while employed there.
cons: Health Insurance was the worst I've seen yet; management lies and manipulates; rare opportunity  to advance in a career unless you suck up to management; very little tuition reimbursement unless you're a part of admin/management; very low pay compared to other hospitals and clinics- the list could on and on.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Astoria, OR
pros: Busy environment. Pleasant building ambiance with lots of potential to be a good small town hospital.
cons: Middle management and supervisors are sorely underqualified and provide very little support or training for staff.  Very cliqish about friends and family in the hiring process.

pros: Small hospital,some doctors nice to work with,close to great food,beautiful scenery,when you have time off is the best time.
cons: Long hours,bickering staff,small town mentality,staff run department with no interference from management.Management not concerned with behavorial problems,incompetent staff.

review_title: CMH is a pretty decent place to work.
job_title: Pharmacy Technician CPhT in Astoria, OR
pros: Better than average pay, nice people to work with, Union
cons: Union, sometimes politics can be annoying

pros: Great staff. Really care about patients.
cons: Horrible management. Lots of turnover because of leaders at the top. They act like they are very smart but really are just power hungry and immature.

pros: Great facility with excellent equipment.
cons: Favoritism is shown for family and friends of individuals in charge of hiring. There is a lot of drama between staff. Certain departments are cliquish and unwelcoming to new comers.

pros: Never lacking for work, mostly good pay
cons: Profit-focused, poor communications with employees
